summary: This document is an email chain from July 2021 between FBI agents, a contractor, an Assistant U.S. Attorney, and an NYPD detective regarding evidence coordination and witness identification for the Ghislaine Maxwell case. It discusses obtaining .avi files from CART, reviewing images, drafting FBI interview reports (302s), and identifying Palm Beach Police Department personnel to authenticate evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's residence.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Subject of the investigation and case preparation discussed in the email chain; the tasks listed are for her prosecution.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned in relation to evidence seized from his Palm Beach residence that requires authentication for the Maxwell case.

persons.name: Assistant United States Attorney
persons.context: Sends the initial task list on February 2, 2021, requesting draft 302s, image reviews, .avi files, and contact for PBPD witnesses to authenticate evidence from Epstein's home.

persons.name: Detective
persons.role: NYPD / FBI Child Exploitation Human Trafficking Task Force
persons.context: Responds on February 4, 2021, providing updates on the requested tasks and identifying a Palm Beach PD Captain as the point of contact.

persons.name: Special Agent
persons.role: FBI New York Field Office, Child Exploitation/Human Trafficking
persons.context: Multiple agents are involved in the email chain coordinating the handoff of files (likely .avi files from CART) and discussing evidence preparation.

persons.name: Palm Beach PD Captain
persons.context: Identified by the NYPD detective as the point of contact for tasks related to evidence from Epstein's Palm Beach residence; contact information is provided.

connections.description: The AUSA requests task updates and information from the NYPD detective, who responds with status reports and contact information.
Coordinate via email about dropping off and receiving files related to the Maxwell case evidence.
Implicit connection as Maxwell's prosecution involves evidence seized from Epstein's residence, indicating their alleged joint criminal activity.
The detective identifies the PBPD Captain as the point of contact for tasks related to Epstein residence evidence.

events.title: Interview of Victim/Witness
events.description: An interview was conducted, likely of a victim or witness, for which draft FBI 302 reports are requested.

events.title: Interview of Victim/Witness
events.description: A second interview was conducted, likely of a victim or witness, for which draft FBI 302 reports are requested.

events.title: Prosecution Task List Sent
events.description: The Assistant U.S. Attorney sends an email with a list of tasks for the Maxwell case, including obtaining 302s, reviewing images, getting .avi files, and finding PBPD witnesses.

events.title: Detective Provides Update
events.description: The NYPD detective responds to the task list, confirming 302s should have been received, noting photos and .avi files are under review, and providing a PBPD point of contact.

events.title: Evidence File Coordination
events.description: FBI agents and a contractor coordinate the handoff of files (likely the .avi files from CART) for the Maxwell case.

locations: Southern District of New York (St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007)
keyFacts: Prosecutors and FBI were actively preparing evidence for the Ghislaine Maxwell trial as of July 2021, including obtaining .avi files from CART and reviewing images.

The evidence needing authentication included items seized from Jeffrey Epstein's Palm Beach residence, such as message pads, indicating the continuity of evidence from the Epstein investigation to the Maxwell prosecution.
The email chain reveals inter-agency coordination between the SDNY U.S. Attorney's Office, FBI New York, NYPD, and Palm Beach Police Department for witness testimony and evidence handling.
A specific list of Palm Beach Police Department personnel (with redacted names) was identified as potential witnesses to authenticate evidence from Epstein's home, ranked by perceived usefulness.
The correspondence indicates that the CART (Computer Analysis and Response Team) was delayed due to the Capitol investigation, showing resource constraints affecting the Maxwell case preparation.
